page.title: 07FIRE RESEARCH STATION
page.content: In 1935 a Furnace Laboratory was opened by the Duke of Kent, and during the war their job was to study the effects of large fires in cities. In 1947 the{Fire Research Station}was set up by the Department of Industrial Research and the insurance companies. It came under the Department of the Environment in 1971. They have a staff of about 130 including graduates in physics, chemistry, engineering, mathematics and architecture. Their job is to research all aspects of fire. More than 800 people die in fires in the U.K. every year with some 600,000 people injured. At the F.R.S. the aim is to minimise these losses. The type of research going on includes testing the efficiency of fire extinguishers, furniture etc. Accurate reconstructions of major fires are carried out in a hanger on the site.
